book_title: Al-Hafiz Zain al-Din al-Iraqi, and his book 'Takmilat Sharh al-Tirmidhi'
text:
Al-Hafiz Zain al-Din al-Iraqi, and his book: "Takmilat Sharh al-Tirmidhi" (Completion of the Explanation of al-Tirmidhi). Dr. Muhammad Yusuf Hafiz Abu Talha (1)

Abstract
This research includes an introduction, two sections, and a conclusion.
As for the introduction, it contains the statement of reasons for choosing the topic, and the research plan.
As for the first section, it contains the biography of Al-Hafiz Abu al-Fadl Zain al-Din Abd al-Rahim ibn al-Husayn al-Iraqi (725 - 806 AH), through which it becomes clear that he was among the major Hadith scholars in the eighth Hijri century, and he raised a blessed generation of Hadith scholars, at the head of whom were Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, Abu Zur'ah al-Iraqi, and Nur al-Din al-Haythami. He has valuable works in Hadith and other sciences that testify to his skill and advancement, among the most important of which is Takmilat Sharh al-Tirmidhi.
As for the second section, it contains the introduction to his valuable book: "Takmilat Sharh al-Tirmidhi". He started his explanation from where Ibn Sayyid al-Nas stopped in: "Al-Nafh al-Shadhi". So he began his explanation from "The Chapter on What Came regarding the Entire Earth Being a Mosque Except the Graveyard and the Bathhouse", and he reached in his explanation to "The Chapter on the Compassion of a Muslim for a Muslim" from the Chapters of Righteousness and Relations (Al-Birr wa al-Silah). Half of the book remained which he did not cover with explanation, and death overtook him before its completion. It is one of the best explanations on Jami' al-Tirmidhi, distinguished by features, the most important of which are: The explainer's concern with the Takkhrij (extraction/referencing) of the chapter's hadith, editing al-Tirmidhi's ruling on it, and discussing him if a contrary view appeared to him, his attention to the Takhrij of what al-Tirmidhi said about: "And in the chapter are hadiths [from so-and-so]", his catching up on what al-Tirmidhi missed of hadiths related to the chapter, his clarification of the jurisprudential issues deduced from the hadiths of Jami' al-Tirmidhi, and his statement of the schools of scholars regarding

As for the conclusion, it contains the most important results and recommendations.
Keywords: The Noble Hadith, Explanations of Hadith, Explanations of Jami' al-Tirmidhi, Al-Hafiz al-Iraqi, Takmilat Sharh al-Tirmidhi.

Introduction
Praise be to Allah alone, and prayers and peace be upon him after whom there is no prophet. As for what follows:
The Prophetic Sunnah is among the most honorable and majestic of sciences, for it is the explainer of the Book of Allah, its interpreter, the clarifier of what is summarised of its verses, and the restricter of many of its generalities. Hence, the scholars of Islam have cared for it since the first era, diversified in its classification, and excelled in its compilation in many ways and numerous forms out of keenness to preserve it.
Among these was: Imam Al-Hafiz Abu Isa al-Tirmidhi, who died in the year 279 AH. He authored various books on the Sunnah, the greatest in benefit and highest in rank being the book Al-Jami' (Jami' al-Tirmidhi), whose fame flew in the East and the West, which made scholars compete in explaining it, clarifying it, and documenting biographies of its men.
Among those who explained it was Judge Abu Bakr Ibn al-Arabi, who died in the year 543 AH, in his book (Aridat al-Ahwadhi), then Al-Hafiz Abu al-Fath Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn Muhammad Ibn Sayyid al-Nas al-Ya'muri, who died in the year 734 AH, in his book (Al-Nafh al-Shadhi), but he did not complete it. So Al-Hafiz Zain al-Din al-Iraqi (d. 806 AH) came and started the explanation from where Ibn Sayyid al-Nas stopped.
Since Al-Iraqi's explanation - despite its importance and abundance of benefits - is still a manuscript that has not yet been printed, I desired

book_title: Al-Hafiz Zain al-Din al-Iraqi, and his book 'Takmilat Sharh al-Tirmidhi'
text:
to introduce it in detail with a brief biography of its author; for I lived with the manuscript of this book for more than three years. So to Allah belongs praise and favor.

Reasons for choosing the topic:
1 - The scientific status of the explainer, for he is one of the major Hadith scholars in the eighth Hijri century, and under his care major Hadith scholars were raised, including Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, Al-Hafiz Al-Haythami, Al-Hafiz Al-Busiri, and Allamah Al-Ayni. And most of the Hadith scholars who came after him scooped from his spring.
2 - The importance of the explained book, for it is an explanation of Jami' al-Tirmidhi, which is one of the six books on which Islam revolves.
3 - The scientific value of the explanation, for it is an explanation full of benefits and investigations, and is distinguished by features, the most important of which are:
(a) The explainer's concern with the Takhrij of the chapter's hadith, editing al-Tirmidhi's ruling on it, and discussing him if a contrary view appeared to him.
(b) His care for the Takhrij of what al-Tirmidhi said about: "And in the chapter are hadiths [from so-and-so]".
(c) Catching up on the hadiths related to the chapter that al-Tirmidhi missed.
(d) His interpretation of the strange vocabulary of the hadith from the mother lexicons and original books of Gharib (strange/uncommon words).
(e) His clarification of the jurisprudential issues deduced from the hadiths of Jami' al-Tirmidhi, and his statement of the schools of scholars regarding the issue.
(f) His critiques of those who preceded him among the explainers of the book like Ibn al-Arabi and Ibn Sayyid al-Nas, and those who preceded him among the biographers of the book's narrators like Al-Mizzi, and those who preceded him in ruling on the hadith like Al-Hakim.
(g) Its being an important reference in documenting al-Tirmidhi's ruling on the hadith.
Because of these features and others, Al-Shawkani praised this precious explanation in the biography of Ibn

book_title: Al-Hafiz Zain al-Din al-Iraqi, and his book 'Takmilat Sharh al-Tirmidhi'
text:
Zain al-Din Abd al-Rahim ibn al-Husayn ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Bakr ibn Ibrahim (1) al-Raziani, Iraqi in origin, Kurdish (2), Mihrani (3), Egyptian, Shafi'i. (4)
His son Abu Zur'ah Ibn al-Iraqi (d. 826 AH) said: "Al-Iraqi by attribution to Iraq of the Arabs, which is the broader region (5), otherwise he is Kurdish in origin. His ancestors resided in a town of the works of Irbil (6): called Razian. They have feats and virtues there, until his father moved to Egypt while he was young with some of his relatives." (7)

Second Demand: His Birth
Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi was born on the twenty-first of the month of Rajab in the year seven hundred and twenty-five in Mansha'at al-Mihrani (8) between Misr (Old Cairo) (9) and Cairo on the bank of the Nile. (10)

Third Demand: His Scientific Upbringing

In the saying of Al-Iraqi's biographers: "Between Misr and Cairo", it is the first application. (See Mu'jam al-Buldan 5/137-143, and Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi and his impact on the Sunnah 1/144-145).

a righteous, devout, virtuous man, raised on engagement with knowledge. He adhered to Sheikh Al-Sharif Taqi al-Din Muhammad ibn Ja'far ibn Muhammad ibn Abd al-Rahim al-Qina'i al-Shafi'i (1) as he used to work in his service, (2) and attended [lessons] with other scholars, and wrote with his hand much of Tafsir, Fiqh, and Raqa'iq (heart-softeners). (3) His mother also was righteous, devout, patient, content, diligent in types of acts of closeness to Allah. (4)
His father took care of his upbringing. Al-Sakhawi (d. 902 AH) said: "His father repeatedly brought him to Al-Taqi, so he would treat him kindly and honor him.... And likewise he made him hear in the year thirty-seven from Prince Sanjar al-Jawli, and Judge Taqi al-Din al-Akhna'i al-Maliki, and others." (5)
So Al-Iraqi grew up in such a righteous environment. Allah bestowed upon him extreme intelligence and quick memory, so he memorized the Quran when he was eight years old, and memorized Al-Tanbih (6), and most of Al-Hawi Al-Saghir by Al-Qazwini (7), and likewise he memorized Al-Ilmam by Ibn Daqiq al-Eid, and perhaps he memorized from it in a single day four hundred lines, in addition to other memorizations. (8)
He studied Arabic, Fiqh and its principles (Usul), and other sciences, but his absorption was in the science of Qira'at (Recitations), and he used to strive in it greatly, until Judge Izz al-Din Ibn Jama'ah (d. 767 AH) advised him, saying to him: "It is a science of much fatigue, little utility, and you possess a burning mind,

He traveled in pursuit of Hadith to Mecca, Medina, Sham (Greater Syria), Aleppo, Homs, Damascus, Gaza, Jerusalem, and Alexandria, completing thirty-six cities which he singled out with Takhrij (referencing) under the name Al-Arba'un al-Buldaniyyah (The Forty of Countries). (3)
Ibn Fahd al-Makki (d. 871 AH) said: "No year passes for him without a journey either for Hajj or seeking Hadith." (4)
Notice: Taqi al-Din Ibn Fahd al-Makki said: "His father died while he was three years old." End quote. (5)
This is a mistake, for Abu Zur'ah Ibn al-Iraqi (d. 826 AH) mentioned that the father of Abu al-Fadl al-Iraqi died in the year seven hundred and sixty-three. (6) So Al-Iraqi, at the time of his father's death, was a man of about thirty-eight years old. Perhaps Ibn Fahd confused the death of Taqi al-Din Muhammad ibn Ja'far al-Qina'i with the death of Al-Iraqi's father, for Al-Qina'i died in the year 728 AH, while Zain al-Iraqi was three years old. (7)

His student Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar (d. 852 AH) said: "He advanced in the art of Hadith such that the sheikhs of the age exaggerated in praising him for knowledge, like Al-Subki, Al-Ala'i, Al-Izz Ibn Jama'ah, Al-Imad Ibn Kathir, and others." End quote. (1)
Below are examples of their praise for him:
His sheikh Al-Isnawi (d. 772 AH) said in the biography of Ibn Sayyid al-Nas: "He explained a piece of Al-Tirmidhi, about two volumes, and the Hafiz of the time Zain al-Din al-Iraqi began completing it, a completion appropriate to its origin." End quote. (2)
Al-Isnawi used to praise his understanding, find his speech in Usul good, listen to his discussions, and say: "His mind is sound, it does not accept error." (3)
His sheikh Taqi al-Din al-Subki (d. 756 AH) mentioned him in his lesson, honoring him for his status, spoke highly of him, and described him with knowledge, proficiency, and understanding. (4) From his honoring of him is that when he came to Cairo in the year seven hundred and fifty-six, the people of Hadith wanted to hear [Hadith] from him, so he refused that and said: I will not narrate except in his presence. Al-Iraqi was absent in Alexandria, so Al-Subki died before he arrived, and did not narrate to them. (5)
Also, his sheikh Al-Ala'i (d. 761 AH) described him with understanding, knowledge, proficiency, and memorization. (6)

His sheikh Izz al-Din Ibn Jama'ah (d. 767 AH) said: "Anyone who claims Hadith in the Egyptian lands other than him is a pretender." (1)
His sheikh Al-Hafiz Taqi al-Din Muhammad ibn Rafi' ibn Hajras al-Salami (d. 774 AH) said—while he was in Mecca in the year 763 AH, and Al-Iraqi had passed by him—: "There is no Muhaddith in Cairo except this one, and Judge Izz al-Din Ibn Jama'ah." When news of the death of Judge Izz al-Din reached him—while he was in Damascus—he said: Now there remains no Muhaddith in Cairo except Sheikh Zain al-Din al-Iraqi." (2)
His student Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar (d. 852 AH) said: "We have not seen in this art anyone more proficient than him, and most of the people of his time graduated under him." End quote. (3) And he said in the beginning of his questions to him: "I asked our master, our role model, our teacher, our benefactor, our extractor (of hadith), Sheikh al-Islam, the unique among notables, the beauty of the days, the Hafiz of the time." End quote. (4) He eulogized him in a long poem (5) in which he praised him greatly, and among it is his saying:
And for sixty years he has not been matched ... nor did the matcher hope to catch up.

Sixth Demand: His Students (2):
Al-Iraqi's personality became famous in the horizons for his deep knowledge in Prophetic Hadith along with participation in other sciences, as the Imams of his time testified. He undertook the task of teaching in Dar al-Hadith al-Kamiliyyah (3), the Old Zahiriyyah School (4), the Fadiliyyah School (5), Ibn Tulun Mosque (6), and other schools. (7) And he revived the Sunnah of dictation sessions (Majalis al-Imla') after they had become extinct. (8) All of that made people travel to him from every direction and side.
Taqi al-Din Ibn Fahd al-Makki said: "He was sought from the easts of the earth and its wests. A massive crowd traveled to him to take from him and hear, the great of them and the small. So they adhered to him, benefited from him, and all the Imams from the notable scholars and Huffaz possessing merit and criticism wrote from him..." (9)

Eighth Demand: His Death:
Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi died following his exit from the bathhouse in Cairo in the middle of the night of Wednesday, the eighth of the month of Sha'ban in the year eight hundred and six, at the age of eighty-one years and three months less a few days. Sheikh Shihab al-Din al-Dhahabi (1) prayed over him, and he was buried at Bab al-Barqiyyah. (2) Ibn Hajar eulogized him in a long poem starting with:
A calamity that did not give respite for choking .. Made tears a neighbor to the eye-sockets (3)
Among the curiosities is what Ibn Hajar also said in the biography of Ibn al-Mulaqqin in Inba' al-Ghumr (4): "These three: Al-Iraqi, Al-Bulqini, and Ibn al-Mulaqqin were the wonder of this age at the head of the century. The first in the knowledge of Hadith and its arts, the second in expansion in the knowledge of the Shafi'i school, and the third in the abundance of compositions. It was destined that each one of the three was born a year before the other, and died a year before him. The first of them, Ibn al-Mulaqqin, was born in year twenty-three and died in year eight hundred and four. Al-Bulqini was born in year twenty-four and died in year eight hundred and five. And Al-Iraqi was born in year twenty-five and died in year eight hundred and six." End quote. May Allah have wide mercy on them and dwell them in His vast gardens.

The book is an explanation of Jami' al-Tirmidhi, except that Al-Iraqi explained it from where Ibn Sayyid al-Nas stopped in his explanation named: "Al-Nafh al-Shadhi". Al-Iraqi said in the introduction of his explanation: "... but death overtook him before its completion ..., and the last I saw of it in his handwriting was his explanation of part of 'Chapter on What Came that the Earth is All a Mosque Except the Graveyard and the Bathhouse' ..., so I began building upon it from the beginning of this chapter." Al-Iraqi also died before completing it. Ibn Fahd said: Takmilat Sharh Jami' al-Tirmidhi (Completion of the Explanation of Jami' al-Tirmidhi) for Ibn Sayyid al-Nas, which is from 'Chapter on What Came that the Earth is All a Mosque Except the Graveyard and the Bathhouse' to his saying during the Book of Righteousness and Relations: 'Chapter on What Came Regarding Covering for Muslims', thirteen volumes. Fourth Demand: On the Explanations of Jami' al-Tirmidhi, and the Position of Al-Iraqi's Explanation Among Them:

First: Explanations of Jami' al-Tirmidhi (1):
The Jami' of Imam Al-Tirmidhi is one of the collections of Sunnah on which Islam revolves, hence it enjoyed the attention of scholars, so more than one explained it. Among its explanations:

It is a medium explanation, its author focused on rulings deduced from hadiths, and jurisprudential issues focusing on the opinions of the Malikis. He did not pay attention to the Takhrij of Al-Tirmidhi's hadiths, nor what Al-Tirmidhi refers to in

Second: The Position of Al-Iraqi's Explanation Among Explanations of Al-Tirmidhi:
Looking at the explanations of Al-Tirmidhi, it becomes clear that the most important of them are the explanation of Ibn al-Arabi, the explanation of Ibn Sayyid al-Nas, its completion by Al-Iraqi, its completion by Abu Zur'ah and Al-Sakhawi, the explanation of Ibn Rajab, and the explanation of Al-Mubarakfuri.
As for Ibn al-Arabi's explanation, it is a brief explanation, in which the Hadith craft is absent except rarely, but it won by virtue of precedence; for how many sayings of his were relied upon by those who came after him.
As for Ibn Rajab's explanation, nothing reached us except a piece of it, which heralds its expansiveness and abundance of material. To Allah is the complaint.
As for Al-Mubarakfuri's explanation, it is late; mostly relying on those before him like Ibn Hajar and Al-Shawkani, but it is the most extensive complete explanation of Jami' al-Tirmidhi, and its author is distinguished by adherence to the Sunnah. Ibn Sayyid al-Nas did not complete

Fifth Demand: The Author's Methodology in His Explanation
Aspects of Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi's methodology in his explanation can be extracted in the following points:
1 - He mentions the text of the chapter from Jami' al-Tirmidhi completely without any change before starting the explanation, which made it like a copy of the copies of the Jami', useful when differences occur in the copies of the Jami', especially in Al-Tirmidhi's rulings on the hadith.

2 - Al-Iraqi's explanation is considered among the objective explanation books that divide the explanation of the hadith into objective paragraphs, and speak on each paragraph separately. Al-Iraqi begins the explanation of the chapter by saying: "Discussion on it is from [several] aspects/faces," then details that. The least found of these aspects is one aspect (1), and sometimes it reaches more than twenty aspects (2).
3 - He usually makes the first aspect for extracting the hadiths that Al-Tirmidhi connected (Isnad), then those he referred to.
4 - He usually makes the second aspect for mentioning hadiths related to the chapter from what Al-Tirmidhi did not mention if the explainer found them. He first lists the names of the Companions who have hadiths, saying: The second in the chapter from what he did not mention from so-and-so, and so-and-so... Then he extracts them hadith by hadith, saying: As for the hadith of so-and-so, so-and-so extracted it from the narration of so-and-so, and mentions its text. And so on.
5 - If the chapter's hadith is among what the authors of the Six Books extracted, or one of them, he extracts it from them, and takes care to exhaust its paths in them, and prioritizes mentioning the one who is most complete in following Al-Tirmidhi. If the chapter's hadith is not with anyone of the authors of the Six Books, he says: The author was unique with it. He often limits himself to this unless there is a benefit in the chain or text, then he extracts it from others. It should be known that the explainer, if he extracts a hadith from the Six Books, intends the place of witness from it, not its origin.
6 - If the hadiths Al-Tirmidhi referred to, or those the explainer caught up on, are from the Six Books, he extracts them from them; otherwise he extracts them usually from the Musnads of Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, Al-Bazzar, and the three Mu'jams of Al-Tabarani.

8 - He judges the hadiths either generally or in detail.
9 - He sometimes explains the reasons for Al-Tirmidhi's rulings on the hadith, and devotes a separate aspect for that.
10 - He sometimes mentions the difference of narrators in the chain or the text.
11 - He alerts to the difference occurring between copies of the Jami' if necessary.
12 - If the narrator whose hadith Al-Tirmidhi extracted is among those with few narrations, he mentions what hadiths he has in Jami' al-Tirmidhi and in the rest of the Six Books, and devotes a separate aspect for this.
13 - He speaks on the narrators regarding impugning and validation (Jarh wa Ta'dil), especially those spoken about, and upon whom the pivot was. He may generalize or detail.
14 - He takes care to clarify the neglected (Muhmal) among narrators, the one named by Kunya, the ambiguous (Mubham), and the Agreed and Separated (Muttafaq wa Muftaraq).
15 - He takes care to interpret strange words, and often mentions his source from books of Gharib and language, such as Al-Sihah by Al-Jawhari, Al-Nihayah by Ibn al-Athir, and Al-Muhkam by Ibn Sidah, and devotes a separate aspect for that.
16 - He takes care to speak on the rulings deduced from the hadith. If there is disagreement among the people of knowledge, he mentions it. He is concerned with mentioning the faces (awjuh) in the Shafi'i school, relying in that mostly on Al-Umm by Al-Shafi'i, Al-Wasit by Al-Ghazali, Al-Aziz by Al-Rafi'i, and Rawdat al-Talibin by Al-Nawawi, and cares for the preferences of Al-Rafi'i and Al-Nawawi.
17 - He sometimes presents potential objections to the ruling deduced from the hadith, then answers them.
18 - He takes care to reconcile between hadiths whose appearance is contradiction, and makes a separate aspect for that.
19 - In case the chapter's hadiths do not suit the chapter heading, he alerts to that.

Sixth Demand: Some of the Author's Resources in His Explanation
The author relied in this explanation of his on the mother books of Hadith and its sciences, books of Tafsir, explanations, history, biographies, Fiqh, language, and others. The explanation is very large, and still a manuscript, so it is very difficult to limit his resources. But what cannot be done completely should not be left completely. So I inventoried the explanation of the Chapters of Jihad from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, to recognize some of his resources.
From books of Tafsir and Causes of Revelation: Asbab al-Nuzul by Al-Wahidi, Tafsir Ibn Jurayj, Tafsir Ibn Jarir al-Tabari, Tafsir Ibn Mardawayh, and Tafsir Abd ibn Humayd.

Conclusion
Praise be to Allah by whose grace good deeds are completed, and prayers and peace be upon the Gifted Mercy. As for what follows:
At the conclusion of this research, I would like to record some results and recommendations that appeared to me during the research:
• Al-Hafiz Abu al-Fadl Zain al-Din al-Iraqi (725 - 806 AH) was among the major Hadith scholars in the eighth Hijri century. He studied under the major scholars of his time without differentiation between Shafi'i, Hanafi, Maliki, and Hanbali. Likewise, students of knowledge studied under him without differentiation, because their concern was to seek knowledge from his spring. The people of knowledge in our time should follow this methodology; for it is a successful methodology and effective cure. Hateful partisanship has been noticed recently in some countries, so to Allah is the complaint.
• A single word from the teacher may be a reason for brilliant success in the life of a student of knowledge if it comes from good intention. The word of Al-Izz Ibn Jama'ah had a visible effect on Al-Iraqi's scientific life, and changed the course of his scientific life until he became one of the major Hadith scholars

in the eighth century, and raised a blessed generation of Hadith scholars, at the head of whom were Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, Abu Zur'ah al-Iraqi, and Nur al-Din al-Haythami.
• Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi was widely read, and he was good at criticism - when necessary - of scholars who preceded him with great politeness and complete humility. His scientific personality appears in his critiques and criticisms.
• Takmilat Sharh al-Tirmidhi is the best explanation on Jami' al-Tirmidhi, although it was not completed, but most of the major explainers who came after him scooped from it.
• Al-Iraqi began his explanation from where Ibn Sayyid al-Nas stopped in his explanation named: "Al-Nafh al-Shadhi". So he began his explanation from "The Chapter on What Came that the Earth is All a Mosque Except the Graveyard and the Bathhouse", but he reached in his explanation to "The Chapter on the Compassion of a Muslim for a Muslim" from the Chapters of Righteousness and Relations. Half of the book remained which he did not cover with explanation, and death overtook him before its completion. His son Abu Zur'ah completed it, and Al-Sakhawi also completed it, according to what biographical books mentioned, but locating their completions was not facilitated. Researchers should search for them in the libraries of the world, or proficient specialists should complete it according to Al-Iraqi's methodology in his explanation; for the path of completing the works of predecessors is a path practiced by the people of knowledge since ancient times, and Al-Iraqi's explanation is a magnificent example of this path.
• Studies and researches written about Al-Iraqi did not benefit from this explanation in highlighting Al-Iraqi's scientific personality, even though it is a great effort that took years of his life. It is recommended to highlight his scientific personality through this book in researches and scientific theses.
I ask Allah Almighty to grant us success to what He loves and pleases.
